Ah, February. The month of love. What better way to spend the month dedicated to relationships other that watching 2D girls on my TV, and better yet, scantally clad 2D girls at that. So I've decided to dedicate an entire month the a genre known as ecchi. Welcome to the first video of ecchi month on my channel, as each Saturday in the month of February, I will review an ecchi show for your amusement. For the first review of ecchi month, we are going to be reviewing Saekano- How toRaise a Boring Girlfriend. I can honestly say this will probably be the best, and least ecchi show I will be reviewing this month. So without further adue, lets get into the start of ecchi month with a very enjoyable and surprising show, Saekano.


Story:

Saekano is about the journey of Tomoya Aki, a high school otaku working part time to support his BD hoarding, as he prepares to kickstart his dream of being a dating-sim game creator. With remarkable luck, he bumps head-first into Megumi Kato-the most beautiful girl he has ever seen. Naturally, the meeting twists his life into a complicated torrent of relationships. Eriri Spencer Sawamura, his half-foreigner childhood friend who's always valued her relationship with MC. Kasumigaoka Utaha, a cold, composed renowned literary genius who shoves everyone aside from our protagonist. This show is the tale of a small not quite doujin circle, but not quite indie studio's journey through the tough territory of comiket and beyond. Now I believe that, for a series that focuses on mainly slice of life comedy, it's not right to hold it to the same criteria of shows of different genres. This show, as a whole, doesn't have an interesting concept at first glance, but this show has one interesting dynamic that made all the difference to me, and that is the character known as Kato Megumi. The way the show handles her character is the real highlight of the show, and the best example of how this show takes an average concept and turns it into something more. Kato's character is Tomoya's dream main protagonist of his game when he has a perfect encounter on a hill in the spring, but he comes to find out his dream heroine is just an average, unnoticeable, simple girl with no presence or any traits befitting of the main heroine he envisioned. The show's sense of direction revolving around Megumi makes her one of my favorite female characters of all time because the show does an amazing job of portraying her character, adding more to her interesting dynamic. The show uses off-focus camera angles, and many other ways to make even the watcher forget Kato is there. In terms of the show's execution, the real value of shows like these is the character interactions, and the scenarios that are set up, as opposed to incredibly compelling narratives and complex story devices. In this regard, the show does an amazing job of setting up scenarios that make use of all the characters interesting character tropes to always keep the show interesting. It takes a slow pace at first, starting off by taking a few episodes to accumulate all the members of the game-making circle, but afterwards becomes quite steady. In terms of the comedy aspect, this show uses a variety of references from the anime and otaku industry. If you are well versed in these, you will find this show incredibly enjoyable because of the subject matter of the comedy. Further on down the line, Saekano takes a detour through a more romantic/drama route, but doesn't veer off course enough to become to cliché, or to lose focus by keeping it fairly light. For the story, this show has a fairly simple concept, but has enough interesting story elements, and dramatic tension to keep you on your toes. The true appeal in this show is its style of comedy, focusing on anime tropes and otaku culture, and if that interests you this show is right down your alley because it does it exceptionally well. Also, despite this being ecchi month, the ecchi was INCREDIBLY toned down, almost to the point of nonexistancy, until episode 10. This is honestly a plus side for me, given I’m not a huge fan of ecchi, but a downside given that this is ecchi month and it’s kinda the theme of the whole thing xD. Episode 0, however, is full of ecchi.


Characters:

Out of all the places this anime excels, the characters are the best example. At first glance most of these characters seem like standard anime character archetypes, but they are all given discerning traits that make them different and lovable in their own way, and honestly by the time the show was over I was sad to see them go. Aki Tomoya is described as an otaku and prefers reading comics and light novels, watching anime, and playing visual novels above anything else. After a chance encounter on a hill, he decides to recruit members for a circle to follow his dream of making a dating sim game that will win the hearts of all who play it. He's just one of those harem protagonists who somehow finds a way to have it in with the 2, arguably 3, most beautiful girls in school, despite his personality. As a character, Aki is one of the shallowest, not really having much to him aside from the fact he is an extreme otaku. We are given some insight as to what makes him tick, as well as his personality and outlook, but other than that he's pretty standard. The next character is Eriri Spencer Sawamura. Eriri is one of the most beautiful girls to attend to Toyogasaki High School. Her family is very affluent. Her father is an English diplomat and she lives in a mansion up in the hills. She is the secret illustrator for an over doujinshi circle called: ''Egoistic Lily'' under the alias Eri Kashiwagi when she participates in doujin activities. Eriri on the surface seems like a standard tsundere, but is given some interesting troupes that keep her from being TOO generic, and is also given some very good characterization through backstory and development. At first, I thought she was going to be just your standard tsundere, but she really is given enough to individualize herself beyond her archetype. The next character is Utaha Kasumigaoka. Utaha is a hardworking girl. Her usual disinterested expression strikes others as an unapproachable person. When she is alone with Tomoya's circle, she reverts to her disdainful self who enjoys making sarcastic remarks. She seems to be calm and quiet, but she actually has a sharp tongue, and can be a little aggressive. She is another example of taking a standard archetype and giving them something to individualize them. She may seem like the emotionless type, but is also given a good amount of backstory and characterization. Also, both of these character's (Eriri and Utaha) backstory and development give us insight into the mind of creators, why they create, and who they create for. This really gives them purpose in the show, especially given the context. These two characters showcase perfectly one thing this show excels at: portraying the relationship between consumer and creator. The next character, and the worst in the show is Michiru Hyodo. Michiru currently attends to a girl’s high school and used to be part of all kinds of clubs on campus but recently started an indie band called Icy tail. She is preparing for her live performances every day. Michiru composes the music in the game by Blessing Software. Michiru’s character is the worst in the show for the sole reason that she makes her appearance in episode 10. THAT’S 2 EPISODES FOR ANY AND ALL CHARACTER DEVELOPMENT. Anything related to her felt forced, and while she was a fun character, given her limited screen time, she felt so empty. Now we move on th the final character, the best character in the show, and the holder of best girl, Megumi Kato. Megumi Kato is Tomoya's classmate, who is hardly noticed by others. She went in the same class as Tomoya since first year, but he never noticed her. After Tomoya had met her during the fate summons, she inspired him to make a dating sim game, and she as his Main Heroine. However, he is disappointed in her real personality. Megumi is an amazing and individual character, as contradictory as it is, because she is not an interesting character. She doesn’t conform to any known archetype in anime, and it really separates her character. The show’s sense of direction in the scenes where Kato is present is fantastic, making the cast and even the watcher completely unaware of her presence. The show does this in many ways including making sure the other characters are the main focus and her positioning within the scenes. The show, with Kato’s personality and direction-sense, were used perfectly to portray Kato’s character, showcasing the thing that most anime seem to forget: characters should be people, not archetypes. All the characters in this show truly feel individual, even though a majority fall under standard archetypes. They are given enough development and individual traits to make them all feel lovable in an industry ruled by character archetypes. This is just one of those shows where after I finished the last episode, I was sad to see them all go, and that speaks waves for the characters and how good they really were, Kato in particular.


Art/Animation:

The art an animation is another place Saekano does a great job. As I’ve mentioned before, the sense of direction centered on Kato is some of the finest I’ve seen, and I’m not even one for all that cinematography stuff. The show does an amazing job of capturing Kato’s unoriginality and lack of presence with the camera angles used, focusing more on the main characters in the scenes where other characters are present, as well as off-focus shots, with Kato out of frame. These things and many more work to shape Kato’s character perfectly. The art style is bright and vibrant, setting a perfect tone for the setting of the show, and the animation is smooth, as well. The show even adds in small moments amidst conversations of mono-color, usually colors used to describe the characters who are speaking or being spoken about. In similar fashion, it also shows brief moments where the outline colors are changed as well. In addition to everything else this show’s art does right, all the character designs portray their characters perfectly and all feel original and add to their lovableness, again Kato in particular. Aside from the weird CGI hand (things?), the art and animation for Saekano was somewhere I thought it excelled for many reasons, most notably its sense of direction. It used flashes of character-specific colors and alternate outline colors to spice things up as well.


Sound:

I can honestly say the sound is one of Saekano’s weaker points. It really is hard for shows like these to grab your attention with their soundtrack, in an anime where creating a perfect atmosphere with a beautiful OST isn’t as needed. That’s not to say the OST is bad in the least, however. This is just one of those cases where it just wasn’t outstanding enough to make a case for itself. Although, the show did do a cover of the Gurren Lagann opening in the last episode, so bonus points for that. The voice actors all played their role very well, with, dare I say, Kato in particular.


Overall:

Saekano is a show that I would recommend to almost anyone. This show just does so much right. The story, while simple has an interesting dynamic that keeps it fresh, the characters, while most of them are standard archetypes all feel individual through traits that they are given and development and backstory that is revealed. And let’s not forget Megumi Kato’s character elevates this show to a whole new level in every regard, not falling under any archetype, and being an original and fresh character in a medium filled with predetermined character standards. This is possible by the shows amazing sense of direction revolving around Kato, and adds to the merit of this show even more. It also uses flashes of character-specific colors during conversations. Lastly, the sound does its job, but in a type of show where OST isn’t all that important to creating an immersive atmosphere, really doesn’t stand out. While in terms of ecchi this may be a terrible show, with little to no ecchi at all with exception to the last 2 episodes and episode 0, this show will go down as one of my all-time favorites. You know you truly enjoy a show when, by the time it’s over, you don’t want to see it end. I really was sad to see this show go by the time it was over. I didn’t want to leave these characters, or the adventure they were having putting together this game. Luckily, a second season is confirmed, so hopefully it comes out very soon. As for alternate recommendations, I think you should check out Shoujo-tachi wa Kouya wo Mezasu. This show is currently airing, but really gives off the same feel as Saekano, where these characters have an adventure in the world of game-making. And this show has Hanazawa Kana. And you should also check out Inou-Battle wa Nichijou-kei no Naka de. This is another show I really enjoyed for being Nisekoi with superpowers, but at the same time with no superpowers. In that purpose, entertainment grew to include romance. There's a lot of show out there that gives you the promise of a romance to fulfill that desire in your heart. Then there's Saenai Heroine no Sodatekata, coming with every other show that shares the same promise.
With that in mind, what makes Saenai Heroine no Sodatekata different from the rest? It follows the same set of character trope, follows the same set of progression, it serves nothing new interms of story either. But what makes it so good? To me, at least, it's the simplicity and relatability.


Most shows out there are pandering to the mainstream audience through a flashy scene, cute characters, self-insert OP (this is a thing), or "fanservice". Yep, fanservice is already ingrained in our community deep enough, we couldn't possibly survive without them by now (or could we?) Saekano do bring them all in (minus the fanservice and self-insert) and managed to make it feel brand new to us. They got the flashy scene and cute characters. 


"But, I see a lot of show with cute characters already."


Hold it right there, gentleman! I'm not done talking! Besides that criteria, we got a PERSONALITY.


That's right people! Personality in a character is hard to be made. You can try but did the audience get the personality you're trying to relay? You need to understand people to create an intricate personality and ironically the supposedly boring character in the show turns out to be the most interesting of all. I'm talking about our main heroine here. I won't go into depths-in analysis but trust me, you'll love her just like me (or not)


The show also tackles a lot in the territory of Otaku culture so, I can't say this is the most beginner-friendly show. You should try this when your understanding of Otaku culture is somewhat enough to understand the basics of tropes  (such a tsundere, yandere, kuudere, galge, eroge, etc).


The art is flashy, somehow reminds me of Shaft's style minus the absurdity. A-1 goes over the top with this one as I saw there were no signs of quality drop. It was consistent and that was great.


The voice actor is good. The music is as usual. Nothing great, nothing bad either.


So, to summarize this, this is a show with light-hearted drama and focuses on the characters building for the second season since that where the real fun begins

Making fun of your cliched characters won't really make them much better and likable.


Although... I did adore Megumi Katou, the titular "boring" character though. She's not the tsundere childhood friend, or ice queen senpai, or little sister-like kouhai, or hot carefree cousin. She's a plain, regular, cute girl who doesn't have much expressions except for her regular deadpan face. For some reason she already appealed to me even with that. Although it will be interesting to see how she develops (she's what the title about, after all), she already is moe to me. Aaanyway, enough talking about Katou (well, she's the titular character though so it should be fine). Comedy, Ecchi, Harem, Romance, School. This combination of tags is seen frequently, and it usually doesn't mean good news. Oversaturated fanservice, recycled tropes, and a lack of plot movement is typically what these shows bring to the table. But Saekano is different, and instead satirizes these qualities to deliver some top-notch comedy. 
Story: 8/10
Like other harem shows, there is admittedly a lack of plot progression, so it's important to go into Saekano knowing the story is far from being over, and that sequels are necessary. To treat the first season as self-contained would be an injustice. As such, the story is more focused on therelationships between the characters rather than the actual making of their game. 

The first season is therefore mostly introduction and set-up for (hopefully) later seasons. Much of the show is the protagonist convincing the other characters to join his circle, which turns out to be quite a difficult task, considering he has complicated histories with all of them. Even after they agree to aid him in his endeavors, it's clear they have their own romance-related reasons for doing so. Can the protagonist truly unite the characters? Hopefully we'll find out. 


Art: 8/10


Not fantastic art, but definitely good enough.


Sound: 9/10


I loved the OP and ED, and thought the quirky soundtracks were appropriate for the comedy. 


Character: 9/10


Really the highlight of the show. As a satire, this show employs the generic tropes we see in harem: the childhood friend, the tsundere, the slightly incestual cousin etc. But by satirizing these tropes, it brings out unexpected scenes and presents scenarios that show just how ridiculous they can be. This ridicule of tropes is most clearly seen in the "main heroine" Megumi Kato. She is the complete opposite of what you'd expect in harem shows; she is neither the overconfident top beauty tsundere, nor the embarrassed shy clumsy unknown classmate. She is average at nearly everything, and she's closer to people in real life than in anime: she has things she doesn't care for, which she will express, but she will also work hard for things she wants to succeed in. She doesn't have some tear-jerking backstory, and the protagonist doesn't need to "rescue" her. 

Admittedly, since the other female characters are parodies of their respective tropes, the show does sometimes just falls back on them instead of trying to do something unique. This balance of being generic while making fun of being generic is hard to achieve, and even though Saekano doesn't do it perfectly, it does do it well. 


Enjoyment: 9/10


I love satirical comedy, so this show was fantastic to watch from beginning to end. If that type of humor isn't your cup of tea, I'd recommend not watching it, because the humor is its main selling point. 


Overall: 9/10


My rating is probably slightly inflated, because it's hard to review comedy objectively. If you're not gonna laugh at the jokes, you will not enjoy the show. But if you want a comedy harem show that parodies itself, Saekano will give you something unique.
